subject: Learning
title: Divided Attention: The Multitasking Illusion
description: A fast breakdown of Divided Attention: The Multitasking Illusion for builders.

hook.text: You think you're texting and listening to a lecture at the same time. You're doing neither well.

buildup.text: Divided attention means splitting focus between two or more tasks simultaneously.

discovery.text: The brain doesn't truly divideâ€”it rapidly switches, losing 20â€“40% of efficiency with each toggle.

twist.text: Only highly automated tasks (walking and talking) can truly run in parallel. Novel tasks cannot.

climax.text: Every time you 'multitask' on complex work, you pay a cognitive tax you can't feel but can measure.

punchline.text: Multitasking is a myth. Task-switching is the reality.

quiz.question: What actually happens when people try to multitask on complex tasks?
options: The brain rapidly switches between tasks, losing efficiency
Both tasks are processed simultaneously and equally
The brain creates a new processing channel
